text:
When unzipping a file to an existing file structure, thus overwriting some
files, these files do not have a modification timestamp afterwards. This can be
observed in the windows file explorer by having empty cells for these files in
the "modified at" column.

The ant script snippet is fairly straightforward:
<unzip
    src="${patch.home}/modifications.zip"
    dest="${project.home}"
/>

It does not touch the created timestamp and does set the "last access" timestamp
to the correct unzip operation time.

The only thing strange is the empty modification date. If you look into "file
properties", you receive the equivalent to a 0-date: 
"Dienstag, 1. Januar 1980, 01:00:00"
(sorry, german windows)

If this is not a bug, but a feature i just happen to miss the advantages for,
just close the issue.
creator: daniel.lindner@abas.de

text: what is the modified time of the artifacts inside the zip?
creator: stevel@apache.org

text: good point: there is no modification date set for the entries inside the zip.
creator: daniel.lindner@abas.de

text:
After further investigation, i can confirm this is not an ant bug.
I used the library "jazzlib" (http://jazzlib.sourceforge.net) to write zipped
files and it seems they just forgot to write a modification date to the zip file.

After switching back to java.util zipping, there are now modification dates in
the zip file that get set properly by the unzip task.

the only improvement i can think of concerning the ant task is a warning if the
modification date is not set. But perhaps its just set to 0 intentionally by the
archive creator.

i will file a bug for the jazzlib people. This is not an ant issue.
creator: daniel.lindner@abas.de

text:
quite impressive response time, btw.
And thanks for the exact hint.
creator: daniel.lindner@abas.de
